options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Cases of VAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP

options.label: C
options.text: Cases of VAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with CAP

options.label: D
options.text: Cases of CAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP

questions.correct_answer: D. Cases of CAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cases of CAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP A fourth category, healthcare-associated pneumonia (HCAP), was introduced recently This category was meant to encompass those cases of CAP that were caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & C. It includes special cases of CAP caused by multidrug-resistant (MDR) pathogens typically associated with HAP.

questions.text: Pneumonia is a type of lung infection. It can cause breathing problems and other symptoms. In community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), you get infected in a community setting. It doesn't happen in a hospital, nursing home, or other healthcare center. Your lungs are part of your respiratory system. Which of the following is a typical pathogen in community-acquired pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Klebsiella pneumonia The “ typical ” category includes pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenza, aureus and gram-negative bacilli such as Klebsiella pneumoniae and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The “ atypical ” organisms include Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, and Legionella species respiratory viruses such as Influenza viruses, Adenoviruses, Human metapneumovirus, and Respiratory syncytial viruses.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, C, D: The “ atypical ” organisms in CAP.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Female gender Risk factors for Legionella infection include Diabetes, Hematologic malignancy, Cancer, Severe renal disease, HIV infection, Smoking, Male gender, A recent hotel stay Ship cruise.

questions.text: Pneumonia is a type of lung infection. It can cause breathing problems and other symptoms. In community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), you get infected in a community setting. It doesn't happen in a hospital, nursing home, or other healthcare center. What is the palpation finding of vocal fremitus in Community-acquired pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased or decreased Palpation may reveal increased or decreased tactile fremitus , The percussion note can vary from dull to flat, reflecting underlying consolidated lung and pleural fluid, respectively.

Increased Increases in airway fluid Pneumonia Pulmonary hemorrhage ARDS Congestive heart failure Increased air entry/turbulence Hyperventilation Mouth breathing Decreased Increased lung volume Hyperinflation Asthma Emphysema/bullous disease Chronic bronchitis Decreased air entry Hypoventilation Airway obstruction Phrenic nerve injury Muscle weakness Lung collapse Increased distance of lung from chest wall Obesity Pleural thickening Pneumothorax Empyema Hemothorax Transudative effusion

questions.text: The chest radiograph of a patient with community-acquired pneumonia shows Pneumatocele. The most probable cause of pneumonia is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S. aureus Occasionally, radiographic results suggest an etiologic diagnosis. Pneumatoceles suggest infection with aureus , and an upper-lobe cavitating lesion suggests tuberculosis . Chest radiography is often necessary to differentiate CAP from other conditions. Radiographic findings may include risk factors for increased severity (e.g., cavitation or multilobar involvements) CT may be of value in a patient with suspected post-obstructive pneumonia caused by a tumor or foreign body or suspected cavitary disease.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B & C. NOT show pneumatoceles usually. Option: D: Atypical organism.

questions.text: A 69-year male patient is diagnosed with Community-acquired pneumonia. On examination, his BP is 70/50 mmHg, RR of 36 bpm, well oriented and blood urea is within normal range. Which mode of treatment would be best for patients?
questions.correct_answer: D. IPD may require ICU admission
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IPD may require ICU admission CURB-65 score is 3 here . Patients with scores of ≥3, may require ICU admission. The CURB-65 criteria include five variables: Confusion (C); Urea >7 mmol/L (U); Respiratory rate ≥30/min (R); Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg (B); and Age ≥65 years. Patients with a score of 0 , can be treated outside the hospital. With a score of 1 or 2, the patient should be hospitalized unless the score is entirely or in part attributable to an age of ≥65 years. In such cases, hospitalization may not be necessary. Among patients with scores of ≥3 , may require ICU admission.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A: For score 0. Option: B: For scores 1-2, based on clinical judgment. Option: C: For scores 1-2, based on clinical judgment.

Extraedge:

RECENT UPDATE - CRB 65 is preferred now which ends the dependency on any blood investigations, therefore, reducing the time required for calculating the score and so, early and prompt treatment can be provided.

questions.text: All of the following pleural fluid findings are indications of complete drainage of pleural effusion in CAP patients EXCEPT?
questions.correct_answer: C. Lactate dehydrogenase concentration of < 1000 U/L
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lactate dehydrogenase concentration of < 1000 U/L Complete drainage of pleural fluid is indicated :- A lactate dehydrogenase concentration of more than 1000 U/L. A significant pleural effusion should be tapped for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes. If the fluid has a pH of less than 7 , a glucose level of less than 2.2 mmol/L , and a lactate dehydrogenase concentration of more than 1000 U/L or if bacteria are seen or cultured, it should be completely drained ; A chest tube is often required, and video-assisted thoracoscopy may be needed for late treatment or difficult cases.

Highyeild:

Indications - for chest drain insertion Pneumothorax Malignant pleural effusion (causing significant SOB) Empyema & complicated parapneumonic pleural effusion Traumatic hemopneumothorax Postoperative e.g, thoracotomy, oesophagectomy, cardiac surgery

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, B & D. Needs complete drainage.

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about the treatment of Community acquired pneumonia?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest radiographic abnormalities are earliest to resolve (6-7 days)

options.label: B
options.text: The site of residence after discharge (nursing home, home with family, home alone) is an important discharge consideration

options.label: C
options.text: If relapse or recurrence is documented, particularly in the same lung segment, the possibility of an underlying neoplasm must be considered

options.label: D
options.text: For a hospitalized patient, a follow-up radiograph ~4–6 weeks later is recommended

questions.correct_answer: A. Chest radiographic abnormalities are earliest to resolve (6-7 days)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chest radiographic abnormalities are earliest to resolve (6-7 days) Chest radiographic abnormalities are slowest to resolve ( 4–12 weeks ), with the speed of clearance depending on the patient’s age and underlying lung disease. Fever and leukocytosis usually resolve within 2–4 days in otherwise healthy patients with CAP , but physical findings may persist longer.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B, C, D: True.

questions.text: In ventilator-associated pneumonia patients, which of the following almost never causes infection without prior exposure to antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa In a high percentage of critically ill patients, the normal oropharyngeal flora is replaced by pathogenic microorganisms Antibiotic exposure poses the greatest risk by far. Pathogens such as aeruginosa almost never cause infection in patients without prior exposure to antibiotics.

Highyeild:

The most important risk factors are: Antibiotic selection pressure, Cross-infection from others Infected/colonized patients Or contaminated equipment, Malnutrition

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Enterobacteriaceae as NON-MDR pathogen in VAP. Option: B. NON-MDR pathogen in VAP. Option: C. NON-MDR pathogen in VAP.

questions.text: Hypersensitivity pneumonitis usually occurs in people who work in places where there are high levels of organic dust, fungus, or molds. Long-term exposure can lead to lung inflammation and acute lung disease. Which of the following is specific to Hypersensitivity pneumonitis?

options.label: A
options.text: Chest x-ray showing ill-defined micro-nodular opacities or hazy ground-glass airspace opacities

options.label: C
options.text: Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) showing BAL lymphocytosis

options.label: D
options.text: Lung biopsy showing the presence of non-caseating granulomas in the vicinity of small airways

questions.correct_answer: C. Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) showing BAL lymphocytosis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) showing BAL lymphocytosis Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), also referred to as extrinsic allergic alveolitis , is a pulmonary disease that occurs due to inhalational exposure to a variety of antigens leading to an inflammatory response of the alveoli and small airways.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Non-specific. In cases of acute and subacute HP, findings may be transient and can include ill-defined micronodular opacities or hazy ground-glass airspace opacities Option: B. Either restrictive or obstructive PFTs can be present in HP , so the pattern of PFT change is not useful in establishing the diagnosis of HP. Option: D. Less A common histologic feature in HP is the presence of noncaseating granulomas in the vicinity of small airways.

Extraedge:

Diagnostic criteria Most widely used are those from Richerson et al. History and physical findings and Pulmonary function tests indicate an interstitial lung disease X-ray film is consistent There is exposure to a recognized cause There is an antibody to that antigen

questions.text: According to the HP study group, which of the following is NOT among the six statistically significant predictors of hypersensitivity pneumonitis?

options.label: B
options.text: Symptoms occurring within an hour of antigen exposure

options.label: C
options.text: Exposure to an antigen known to cause HP

questions.correct_answer: B. Symptoms occurring within an hour of antigen exposure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Symptoms occurring within an hour of antigen exposure Although there is no set of universally accepted criteria for arriving at a diagnosis of HP , diagnosis depends foremost on establishing a history of exposure to an offending antigen that correlates with respiratory and systemic symptoms Although not meant as a set of validated diagnostic criteria, a clinical prediction rule for predicting the presence of HP has been published by the HP Study Group. They identified six statistically significant predictors for HP, the strongest of which was exposure to an antigen known to cause HP the presence of serum precipitins recurrent symptoms occurring 4–8 hr after antigen exposure crackles on inspiration, and weight loss.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A, C & D. They are among the criteria.

Extraedge:

Diagnostic criteria Most widely used are those from Richerson et al. History and physical findings and Pulmonary function tests indicate an interstitial lung disease X-ray film is consistent There is exposure to a recognized cause There is an antibody to that antigen

questions.text: Acute eosinophilic pneumonia is a severe and rapidly progressive lung disease that can cause fatal respiratory failure. Since this disease exhibits totally different clinical features to other eosinophilic lung diseases. Which of the following is NOT included in the diagnostic criteria of acute eosinophilic pneumonia?

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of parasitic, fungal, or other infection

questions.correct_answer: A. No clinical response to corticosteroids
questions.explanation:
Solution:

No clinical response to corticosteroids Acute eosinophilic pneumonia is a syndrome characterized by Fevers , Acute respiratory failure that often requires mechanical ventilation, Diffuse pulmonary infiltrates , and Pulmonary eosinophilia in a previously healthy individual Acute eosinophilic pneumonia is often mistaken for acute lung injury or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) until a BAL is performed and reveals >25% eosinophils. Quick clinical response to corticosteroids. One of the characteristic features of acute eosinophilic pneumonia is the high degree of corticosteroid responsiveness and the excellent prognosis.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B, C & D. These are included in criteria.

questions.text: 21 year old college student presents with complaints of malaise, headache, fever upto 38.3 degree Centigrade, chills and a non-productive cough and Joint pain for the past week. His temp is 38.1 degree centigrade. Heart rate is 90 /min, respiratory rate is 20 /min and blood pressure is 118/75 mm Hg. On physical examination the patient appears fatigued. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral diffuse wheezes and rales. X-ray of the chest reveals bilateral infiltrates. The doctor prescribed ceftriaxone, but the patient failed to show any improvement over the subsequent week. Which antibiotic should the physician prescribe instead?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Azithromycin The patient’s presentation is most consistent with atypical pneumonia likely caused by Mycoplasma pneumoniae . Mycoplasma is the most common cause of atypical pneumonia and the second most common cause of pneumoniae. It has a very nonspecific presentation. URTI (Tracheobronchitis/Pharyngitis) is the most common pulmonary manifestation. The patient here presents with URTI, non-responsive to Ceftriaxone. All the above features are suggestive of mycoplasma pneumoniae.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Ampicillin: Mycoplasma has no cell wall so it is not sensitive to any penicillin, Ampicillin; which acts by inhibiting cell wall synthesis. Option: C. Clindamycin: It is used for the treatment of anaerobic bacterial infections , not for mycoplasma. Option: D. Fourth generation Cephalosporin: Cephalosporins also act by inhibiting cell wall synthesis, so not effective in mycoplasma.

Extraedge:

Extrapulmonary manifestations are common like Cold agglutinin disease, Erythema multiforme, GBS, SJS, Myocarditis, Encephalitis, and Arthralgia with adenopathy.

questions.text: Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia (CEP) is an idiopathic disorder characterized by an abnormal and marked accumulation of eosinophils in the interstitium and alveolar spaces of the lung. Which of the following is pathognomonic of chronic eosinophilic pneumonia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Chest CT Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia is a more indolent syndrome that is characterized by pulmonary infiltrates and eosinophilia in both the tissue and blood. Most patients are female nonsmokers with a mean age of 45, and patients do not usually develop acute respiratory failure and significant hypoxemia appreciated in acute eosinophilic pneumonia. CXR and CT Chest shows migratory bilateral peripheral or pleural-based opacities . Although this “ photographic negative pulmonary edema” appearance on chest x-ray and chest CT is pathognomonic of chronic eosinophilic pneumonia, <25%of patients present with this finding.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. IgE levels are not required for diagnosis Option: C. Lung biopsy is also often not required to establish a diagnosis, but may show accumulation of eosinophils and histiocytes in the lung parenchyma and interstitium, as well as cryptogenic organizing pneumonia, but with minimal fibrosis. Option: D. BAL eosinophilia is also an important distinguishing feature with mean BAL eosinophil counts of ~60%.

questions.text: Mononeuritis multiplex in eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) most commonly involved?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Peroneal nerve EGPA was known as Churg Strauss syndrome this complex syndrome is characterized by eosinophilic vasculitis that may involve multiple organ systems including the Lungs, Heart, Skin, GI tract, and Nervous system. Mononeuritis multiplex most commonly involves the peroneal nerve , but also involves the ulnar, radial, Internal popliteal, and occasionally, cranial nerves may also occur and are important causes of death. Despite treatment, neurologic sequelae often do not completely resolve.

Highyeild:

The primary features of EGPA include: Asthma, Peripheral eosinophilia, Neuropathy, Pulmonary infiltrates, Paranasal sinus abnormality, and Presence of eosinophilic vasculitis

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A , B & C. are not the most commonly involved nerves.

questions.text: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a condition in which the lungs become scarred and breathing becomes increasingly difficult. It's not clear what causes it, but it usually affects people who are around 70 to 75 years old and is rare in people under 50. Which of the following is a treatment option in Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of above Historically , IPF was felt to be refractory to medical therapy with lung transplantation the only viable therapeutic option. This dogma changed in 2014 with large clinical trials that demonstrated that antifibrotic therapy (pirfenidone and nintedanib) can slow the decline of lung function in IPF patients. Physical therapy and supplemental oxygen, when indicated, can improve exercise tolerance and reduce the likelihood of developing pulmonary hypertension.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Historically, IPF was felt to be refractory to medical therapy with lung transplantation the only viable therapeutic option. Option: B. Antifibrotic therapy (pirfenidone and nintedanib) can slow the decline of lung function in IPF. Option: C. Physical therapy and supplemental oxygen, when indicated, can improve exercise tolerance and reduce the likelihood of developing pulmonary hypertension.
